results.title: Animations in the studio
results.creator_credit: Lawrie Lawler and Centre for Educational Television Overseas
results.brief_description: Examines the construction lighting and use of a simple slide animation which allows a sequence of words or symbols to be revealed on the screen at exactly the right moment. Also demonstrates moire fringes, the use of magnets and complicated cardboard animations.

results.title: Animation pie
results.brief_description: A group of high school students go through the processes and experiences of making several animated films. Covers the techniques of flip books, drawing on film, pixilation, cut-outs and clay animation.

results.title: Animation on film
results.brief_description: An introduction to the principles and techniques of film animation, the equipment needed - the rostrum, animation bench, and mounting of the camera are discussed. The planning of animation, and the care and accuracy needed throughout all stages are shown in detail. Roland Kemp is animation advisor.

results.title: Animation in the school classroom
results.creator_credit: Alexander Milsky and Alex Milsky Productions
results.brief_description: A very detailed film showing students and teachers how animation is possible with a minimum of equipment. It gives advice on what paper to use, methods of production, importance of teamwork, advantages of experiment, how to make a light box, how to make an animation table and the requirements of the camera. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.

results.title: Animation: a living art form
results.brief_description: Uses the 1971 motion picture “Shinbone Alley” to show the development of an animated film from the script through the storyboard and animation to the final print. No other credits available.

results.title: Animated women
results.brief_description: Five very short films made by women give us glimpses of aspects of the lives of some women. The films include: 1. “The Ballad of Lucy Jordan” by Ian Moo Young. Music by Dr Hook and The Medicine Show (stills and animation) 2. “Later that night” by Barbara Bottner. Music by Phillip Namanworth (animation) 3. “Brews and potions” by Deborah Healy. Music by Valentino Brothers (animation) 4. “Made for each other” by Barbara Bottner. Music by Phillip Namanworth. 5. “A la votre” by Monique Renault. Music by Rene Koenig.

results.title: Animated genesis (TEFC)
results.brief_description: An allegory of the creation of the world, of man’s enslavement by the machine, motivated by Greed, which is personified as an enormous and menacing spider. It is eventually overthrown by the intervention of Goodness, but not before atomic warfare has resulted. The Foldes made the film at home, drawing all 32,000 pictures, and showed the 16mm result to Sir Alexander Korda, who had it blown up to 35mm for theatrical release. No other credits available.

results.title: Animals without backbones
results.brief_description: What kinds of structures do these animals have? How do such bodies move about? How are their bodies supported? Nature photography points out the characteristics of the anthropods, spiny-skinned animals, molluscs, sponges, bag-like animals, and earthworms, and shows these animals carrying out some of their life functions.

results.title: Animals: ways they move
results.brief_description: Illustrates how animals move in water, on land and in the air. Explains that an animal’s movement helps it to acquire food, to protect itself from enemies, to find a home, to move from place to place, and to adapt to its environment.
results.description: Illustrates how animals move in water, on land and in the air. Explains that an animal’s movement helps it to acquire food, to protect itself from enemies, to find a home, to move from place to place, and to adapt to its environment.

results.title: Animals of the zoo
results.brief_description: A visit to a zoo at feeding time, provides an opportunity to study the food and eating habits of various animals: lion, tiger, gorilla, chimpanzee, eland, bison, black and polar bears. Also contains a rare short sequence of a Tasmanian tiger, referred to as a wolf dog. Habitats and characteristics of each are described.
